channel.title: NYT > Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Silk Road, Online Black Market, Reduced Users’ Risks, Defense Says
item.description: Lawyers for the convicted founder of the website, Ross W. Ulbricht, have asked the sentencing judge to disregard six overdose deaths the government is linking to the website.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: New on Snapchat, Music Videos
item.description: Videos released on the platform this week by Goldroom, an electronic musician, will be the latest step in the company’s evolving role as a media outlet.
item.dc:creator: BEN SISARIO
item.media:credit: Sam Comen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Josh Legg, known as Goldroom, with Nikki Segal making a music video for Snapchat. The messaging app is branching out as an outlet for music.

item.title: Six Years in, Obama Joins Twitter Universe (but He’s Not Following You)
item.description: President Obama inaugurated his own Twitter account on Monday, after years of complaining of being trapped in a Washington bubble.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: President Obama’s Twitter profile. It did not take long for him to attract one million followers.

item.title: Kijiji, a Flop in the U.S., Rules Online Classifieds in Canada
item.description: The eBay-owned website, whose name means “village” in Swahili, attracts three times as many users in Canada as Craigslist, which dominates in the United States.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
item.media:credit: Ryan Enn Hughes for The New York Times
item.media:description: Janet Bannister, a general partner at a seed capital investment fund, founded Kijiji, a Canadian online classified service owned by eBay. Although Kijiji is now used by almost half of all Canadians, eBay continues to advertise it heavily.

item.title: Singapore’s Postal Service Reinvents Itself for the Digital Age
item.description: With traditional mail fading, SingPost has transformed into a provider of logistics and marketing services to companies eager to tap the e-commerce boom in Asia.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA STEVENSON
item.media:credit: Edwin Koo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Following Amazon’s model, Singapore Post is building 24 warehouses in 12 countries to store products for companies.

item.title: Bits Blog: Apple Acquires Coherent Navigation, a GPS Start-Up
item.description: The purchase further bolsters Apple’s mapping technology and services.
item.dc:creator: MIKE ISAAC
item.media:description: Apple released its own mapping service, which uses both in-house technology and some licensed from TomTom, in 2012.

item.title: Appeals Court Upholds Apple’s Patent Victory Over Samsung
item.description: The federal court also ruled that the iPhone’s overall look could not be protected and part of the $930 million in damages must be recalculated.
item.dc:creator: BRIAN X. CHEN
item.media:description: Ads for a Samsung Galaxy phone, left, and an Apple iPhone, right, in Seoul.

item.title: Kering Sues Alibaba Again Over Counterfeit Luxury Goods
item.description: The company, whose labels include Gucci and Yves Saint Laurent, says the e-commerce giant uses vendors that are selling high-end knockoffs.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR

item.title: Bits Blog: Kijiji, the Craigslist of Canada, Run by eBay
item.description: The eBay-owned website, whose name means “village” in Swahili, attracts three times as many users in Canada as Craigslist, which dominates in the United States.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Fake Diplomas, Real Cash: Pakistani Company Axact Reaps Millions
item.description: According to former insiders, company records and an analysis of its websites, a secretive software company is selling fake academic degrees on a global scale.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.media:credit: Sara Farid for The New York Times
item.media:description: Axact, which has its headquarters in Karachi, Pakistan, ostensibly operates as a software company.

item.title: The Right Baits the Left to Turn Against Hillary Clinton
item.description: In digital campaigns, conservative groups are sending a steady stream of posts attacking Hillary Rodham Clinton, some of them specifically designed to be spotted, and shared, by liberals.
item.dc:creator: ASHLEY PARKER and NICK CORASANITI
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Colin Reed of America Rising PAC, which created Twitter posts disparaging Hillary Rodham Clinton, and designed to be shared by liberals.

item.title: A Russian Smartphone Has to Overcome Rivals and Jokes About Its Origin
item.description: Few people looking to buy a state-of-the-art smartphone would even think about a Russian model, but the makers of the YotaPhone aspire to change that.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: The YotaPhone 2 was presented to the media in Moscow last month. Young technology buffs in Russia gave it mixed reviews.

item.title: Workspace: Natalia Maria Ruderman of IBM: A Sweet Spot for Global Traditions
item.description: Ms. Ruderman, a vice president and chief financial officer for IBM Latin America, keeps an open mind and an open office.
item.dc:creator: Interview by PATRICIA R. OLSEN
item.media:credit: Tuca Vieira for The New York Times
item.media:description: Natalia Maria Ruderman, vice president and chief financial officer for IBM Latin America in São Paulo, Brazil.

item.title: For the Highest-Paid C.E.O.s, the Party Goes On
item.description: Four chief executives at five companies with ties to John C. Malone, who built a cable and communications empire, were awarded more than $350 million last year.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GELLES
item.media:description: Some of the highest-paid executives and their boss. From left: Gregory B. Maffei, C.E.O. of Liberty Media, earned $74 million; Michael T. Fries, C.E.O. of Liberty Global, earned $112 million; John C. Malone is the chairman of both companies and sits on the board of Discovery Communications; David M. Zaslav, C.E.O. of Discovery Communications, earned $156 million.

item.title: Farmers Flying Drones May Soon Be Given Clearance
item.description: Few people are as excited about proposed rules that would allow people to fly small unmanned aircraft for commercial reasons as the farmers who use them to gather crop information.
item.dc:creator: JULIE TURKEWITZ
item.media:credit: Michael Ciaglo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jean Hediger, a Colorado farmer, using a drone to pinpoint which parts of her fields need fertilizer, water, weed killer or seed.

item.title: Netflix Said to Be in Early Talks With Chinese Companies
item.description: America’s video-streaming leader is in preliminary talks with Chinese media companies, as it aims to expand its presence from more than 50 countries to 200 by the end of next year.
item.dc:creator: EMILY STEEL

item.title: Bits Blog: Penn State’s College of Engineering Hit by Cyberattack
item.description: Universities are increasingly a target for hackers because they handle vast amounts of personal and financial information for students and employees, as well as sensitive research.
item.category: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
item.dc:creator: NICOLE PERLROTH
item.media:credit: Nabil K. Mark/Centre Daily Times, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Investigators said that the sophisticated cyberattack against Pennsylvania State University lasted more than two years.

item.title: Google to Test Bubble-Shaped Self-Driving Cars in Silicon Valley
item.description: Tests of the cars, which look like golf carts with doors, are expected to place the search giant closer to its goal of hands-free, foot-free driving.
item.dc:creator: CONOR DOUGHERTY and AARON M. KESSLER
item.media:description: A prototype of Google's self-driving car.

item.title: Carl Icahn Invests $100 Million in Lyft
item.description: The investment is an extension of a $530 million round that the ride-hailing start-up raised in March, valuing it at $2.5 billion.
item.dc:creator: MIKE ISAAC and ALEXANDRA STEVENSON
item.media:description: A Lyft car in San Francisco last year.

item.title: Bits Blog: Unearthing the Enigma of Bitcoin’s Birth
item.description: Conversations with those most deeply involved in Bitcoin yielded a quiet but widely held consensus, and new hints drew an investigator further into the chase.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
